QuestionTxt: (I'd like or get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't fell favorable toward the person and that you don't care too much for that person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one.)...How would you rate: Donald Trump?
SurveyOrg: Center for Political Studies at the Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan, with data collection by Westat, Inc.
SurveySponsor: American National Election Studies (ANES); Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan; Stanford University
SourceDoc: 2020 Post-Election Survey - B
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline; Computer-Assisted telephone interview (CATI); Web-based survey; null

QuestionTxt: Overall, do you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of...Donald Trump?
SourceDoc: Trump, Biden favorability unchanged as 2020 race heads into final week
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

SourceDoc: Americans open to Biden’s approach to crises
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline; Computer-Assisted telephone interview (CATI); Web-based survey
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

QuestionTxt: Is your overall opinion of Donald Trump very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable?
SourceDoc: After the ballots are counted: Conspiracies, political violence, and American exceptionalism
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

RespTxt: More for what he's done as president
QuestionTxt: Do you have a very favorable/somewhat favorable/somewhat unfavorable/very unfavorable view of (Donald) Trump more because of what he's done as president or more because of who he is and what he stands for?
SourceDoc: Socially distant: How our divided social networks explain our politics
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

QuestionTxt: For each of the following individuals, please indicate if you have an unfavorable or favorable impression of that person. If you don’t know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too....Very unfavorable, somewhat unfavorable, somewhat favorable, very favorable...Donald Trump
SurveyOrg: The AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research
SourceDoc: How Americans describe 2020 Democrats, Trump
IntMethod: Computer-Assisted telephone interview (CATI); Web-based survey
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

QuestionTxt: Overall, do you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of...Donald Trump?
SourceDoc: Trump's favorability and perceptions of COVID-19 response stagnate post-convention
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (How favorable or unfavorable is your opinion of each of the following (2020) presidential candidates?...Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable, heard of, no opinion, never heard of)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Who Won The First 2020 Presidential Debate?
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: Wave 1 of the survey was conducted September 21-28, 2020 (N=3133). Wave 2 respondents were re-interviewed September 29-30, 2020 (N=1827). The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: Wave 1 of the survey was conducted September 21-28, 2020 (N=3133). Wave 2 respondents were re-interviewed September 29-30, 2020 (N=1827). The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person and that you don't care too much for that person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one.)...How would you rate...Donald Trump?
SurveyOrg: Center for Political Studies at the Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan, with data collection by Westat, Inc.
SurveySponsor: American National Election Studies (ANES); Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan
SourceDoc: American National Election Studies: 2020 Pre-Election Survey - A
SampleDesc: National adult and members of the 2016 ANES Panel
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline; Computer-Assisted telephone interview (CATI); Web-based survey; null

QuestionTxt: (I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person and that you don't care too much for that person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person. SurveyOrg: AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research
SourceDoc: Many in US distrust campaign info
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

QuestionTxt: Overall, do you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of...Donald Trump?
SourceDoc: Biden enjoys post-convention bump in favorability
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: Please say whether your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable....Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Summer Unrest over Racial Injustice Moves the Country, But Not Republicans or White Evangelicals
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

QuestionTxt: Would you say your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable?...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Civic Engagement, Young Adult Activism, and the 2018 Midterm Elections
SampleDesc: National adult with oversamples of those age 18-29 and residents of OH, IL, MI, WI, and MN
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult sample.

QuestionTxt: For each of the following individuals, please indicate if you have an unfavorable or favorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too...Donald Trump...Very unfavorable, somewhat unfavorable, somewhat favorable, very favorable, don't know enough to say
SurveyOrg: AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research
SourceDoc: AP-NORC poll: More support than oppose impeachment probe
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

QuestionTxt: Thinking about Donald Trump’s ability to handle a number of things, how confident are you that Donald Trump can do each of the following?...Negotiate favorable trade agreements with other countries...Very confident, somewhat confident, not too confident, not at all confident
SurveySponsor: Pew Research Center for the People & the Press
SourceDoc: By a Narrow Margin, Americans Say Senate Trial Should Result in Trump’s Removal
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The American Trends Panel (ATP), created by Pew Research Center, is a nationally representative panel of randomly selected US adults recruited from landline and cellphone random-digit-dial surveys. Panelists participate via monthly self-administered web surveys. Panelists who do not have Internet access are provided with a tablet and wireless Internet connection. The ATP is managed by Ipsos.

StudyNote: The American Trends Panel (ATP), created by Pew Research Center, is a nationally representative panel of randomly selected US adults recruited from landline and cellphone random-digit-dial surveys. Panelists participate via monthly self-administered web surveys. Panelists who do not have Internet access are provided with a tablet and wireless Internet connection. The ATP is managed by Ipsos.

QuestionTxt: Would you say your overall opinion of Donald Trump is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable?
SourceDoc: Americans Deeply Divided by Party on Ideals of Religious and Ethnic Pluralism
SampleDesc: National adult with oversamples of residents of OH/IL/MI/WI/MN
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: Please say whether your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable....Donald Trump
SourceDoc: From Impeachment to Issue Priorities, Democrats and Republicans Inhabiting Increasingly Different Worlds
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote: Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC’s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

SourceDoc: Suffolk University/Boston Globe Poll Shows Patient-to-Nurse Limit Ballot Question Flips to the No Side
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline

QuestionTxt: (If the following were to vote to impeach or remove President (Donald) Trump from office, would it make you more or less favorable towards them?...Much more favorable, somewhat more favorable, make no difference, somewhat less favorable, much less favorable)...Your member of Congress
SourceDoc: Most Americans Think Trump Committed An Impeachable Offense
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (Thinking about Donald Trump's ability to handle a number of things, how confident are you that Donald Trump can do each of the following?)...Negotiate favorable trade agreements with other countries...Very confident, somewhat confident, not too confident, not at all confident
SurveySponsor: Pew Research Center for the People & the Press
SourceDoc: Most Democrats Are Excited by ‘Several’ 2020 Candidates – Not Just Their Top Choice
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The American Trends Panel (ATP), created by Pew Research Center, is a nationally representative panel of randomly selected US adults recruited from landline and cellphone random-digit-dial surveys. Panelists participate via monthly self-administered web surveys. Panelists who do not have Internet access are provided with a tablet and wireless Internet connection. The ATP is managed by Ipsos.

QuestionTxt: (If the following were to vote to impeach or remove President (Donald) Trump from office, would it make you more or less favorable towards them?...Much more favorable, somewhat more favorable, make no difference, somewhat less favorable, much less favorable)...Democratic member of Congress
SourceDoc: Most Americans Think Trump Committed An Impeachable Offense
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: If the following were to vote to impeach or remove President (Donald) Trump from office, would it make you more or less favorable towards them?...Much more favorable, somewhat more favorable, make no difference, somewhat less favorable, much less favorable...Republican member of Congress
SourceDoc: Most Americans Think Trump Committed An Impeachable Offense
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: If the following were to vote to impeach or remove President (Donald) Trump from office, would it make you more or less favorable towards them?...Much more favorable, somewhat more favorable, make no difference, somewhat less favorable, much less favorable...Republican member of Congress
SourceDoc: Most Americans Think Trump Committed An Impeachable Offense
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

SourceDoc: Most Americans Think Trump Committed An Impeachable Offense
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by Ipsos using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (Now, please report whether your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: PRRI/MTV National Youth Survey
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national YouthPulse panel. The initial sample drawn from the YouthPulse panel was adjusted using pre-stratification weights so that it approximates the overall population (15 to 24 year olds) in the US defined by the latest Current Population Survey.  Next, a probability proportional to size sampling scheme was used to select a representative sample. Once assigned to the survey, panel participants received an email notification reminder on day four, seven and twelve of the field period. The YouthPulse panel is a nationally representative probability sample of teens and young adults age 15 to 24 years old. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling. Participants under the age of 18 were included in the panel following the receipt of parental consent. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into the panel; and are generally limited to how many surveys they can take within a given time period.

QuestionTxt: What is your overall opinion of...Donald Trump?...Very favorable, mostly favorable, very unfavorable, mostly unfavorable
SourceDoc: Pew Research Center's American Trends Panel Poll
SampleDesc: National adult (2066 panelists completed by web and 1778 panelists completed by phone)
IntMethod: Telephone Interview, Cell Phone; Telephone Interview, Landline; Computer-Assisted telephone interview (CATI); Web-based survey
StudyNote:
2066 respondents were interviewed online and 1778 by telephone. 
The American Trends Panel (ATP), created by the Pew Research Center, is a nationally representative panel of randomly selected US adults living in households. Respondents who self-identify as Internet users (representing 89% of US adults) participate in the panel via monthly self-administered Web surveys, and those who do not use the Internet participate via telephone or mail. The panel is being managed by Abt SRBI. Question wording in this topline is that from the web version of the survey. Question wording and format was adapted for the paper questionnaire delivered by mail.

RespTxt: Time for a change; men/Congress doing a bad job
QuestionTxt: As you may know, more women are running for US Congress this year (2018) than in the past. Why do you think that is the case?
QuestionNote: Adds to more than 100% due to multiple responses.
SourceDoc: Most Americans say more women running for Congress is a good thing, as hope for a female president grows
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The American Trends Panel (ATP), created by Pew Research Center, is a nationally representative panel of randomly selected US adults recruited from landline and cellphone random-digit-dial surveys. Panelists participate via monthly self-administered web surveys. Panelists who do not have Internet access are provided with a tablet and wireless Internet connection. The panel is being managed by Gfk Knowledge Networks.

QuestionTxt: (Do you have a very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, or very unfavorable view of the following world leaders?)...United States President Donald Trump
SurveySponsor: The Chicago Council on Global Affairs
SourceDoc: Chicago Council on Global Affairs Poll
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (Do you have a very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, or very unfavorable view of the following world leaders?)...United States President Donald Trump
SurveySponsor: The Chicago Council on Global Affairs
SourceDoc: Chicago Council on Global Affairs Poll
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: On a scale from 0 to 100, where 0 = extremely unfavorable and 100 = extremely favorable, what is your opinion of the following individuals?...Donald Trump?
SourceDoc: Young Americans' Attitudes toward Politics and Public Service Survey
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: Would you say your overall opinion of Donald Trump is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable?
SourceDoc: American Democracy in Crisis: The Challenges of Voter Knowledge, Participation, and Polarization
SampleDesc: National adult with oversamples of residents of Illinois, Ohio, Michigan, Minnesota, and Wisconsin
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult sample.

Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult sample.

QuestionTxt: (Now we'd like your views on some political leaders or groups. Please say whether your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable.)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: PRRI American	 Values Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
1720 respondents were interviewed online, and 290 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national U.S. adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC¿s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

QuestionTxt: (For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too....Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable, don't know enough to say)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (Now, I'd like to rate your feelings toward some people and organizations, with one hundred making a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold. You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization. If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Donald Trump...Give...Donald Trump a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. IntMethod: Telephone Interview
StudyNote: Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2012 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably/almost certain/50-50 to vote in the 2016 election.

If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too.)...Donald Trump...Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable
SurveyOrg: AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research
SourceDoc: Associated Press-NORC GenForward Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
1610 respondents were interviewed online, and 330 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC¿s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month.

QuestionTxt: (For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too.)...Donald Trump...Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable

IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
1610 respondents were interviewed online, and 330 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC¿s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month.

QuestionTxt: (Do you have a favorable or unfavorable view of the following individuals?...Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable, don't have enough information to rate, never heard of)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Young Americans' Attitudes toward Politics and Public Service Survey
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too....Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable)...Melania Trump
SourceDoc: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too....Donald Trump)...Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable, don't know enough to say
SourceDoc: Associated Press-NORC GenForward Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
1801 respondents were interviewed online, and 157 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States. 45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month

QuestionTxt: (Now, I'd like to rate your feelings toward some people and organizations, with one hundred meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold. You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization. If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Donald Trump...Give...Donald Trump a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. QuestionTxt: (I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person and that you don't care too much for that person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one.)...How would you rate...Donald Trump? (If Don't know, ask:) When you say don't know, do you mean that you don't know who the person is, or do you have something else in mind?
SurveyOrg: Center for Political Studies at the Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan, with data collection by Westat
SurveySponsor: American National Election Studies (ANES); Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan
SourceDoc: American National Election Studies: 2016 Pre-Election Survey - B
IntMethod: Face-to-face interview; Web-based survey; Computer-assisted personal interview (CAPI)

SurveyOrg: The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research
SurveySponsor: Associated Press; NORC at the University of Chicago
SourceDoc: Associated Press-NORC Gender Discrimination in the US Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
832 respondents were interviewed online, and 264 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC?s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month.

QuestionTxt: (For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too.)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Associated Press-NORC GenForward Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
1684 respondents were interviewed online, and 167 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States. 45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month

NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States. 45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month

SourceDoc: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

SurveyOrg: The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research
SourceDoc: Associated Press-NORC Campaign  Issues Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
821 respondents were interviewed online, and 201 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC¿s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too....Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Associated Press-NORC GenForward Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
1759 respondents were interviewed online, and 73 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.			
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month

NORC's AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.			
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month

QuestionTxt: (Do you have a favorable or unfavorable view of the following individuals?...Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable, don't have enough information to rate, never heard of)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Young Americans' Attitudes toward Politics and Public Service Survey
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: We'd like to get your feelings about some of the people who are in the news these days. We'll show the name of a person or group and we'd like you to rate that person or group using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person and you don't care too much for that person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person....Donald Trump
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to investigate whether media accounts contribute to the persistence of biological racism among White Americans. The total 2,034 White, non-Hispanic adult respondents were assigned randomly to two treatment groups (race as genetics condition or race as social construction condition) or a control. Respondents were then asked questions intended to measure feelings regarding whether biological racial differences exist, three strikes legislation, the death penalty, and racial resentment. This allowed for deeper understanding of whether ostensibly innocuous messages about race, health, and genetics have consequences on public attitudes towards race. * = Less than .5 percent.
SubPopulation: Asked of treatment group 1, respondents who read a fictitious news article attributing racial disparities in heart disease to genetic factors (n=695)
SourceDoc: TESS Survey
SampleDesc: National White, non-Hispanic adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote:
Weighted results shown. Individual-level unweighted data with weight variable available for download 
for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.

QuestionTxt: (For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too.)..Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: We'd like to get your feelings about some of the people who are in the news these days. We'll show the name of a person or group and we'd like you to rate that person or group using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person and you don't care too much for that person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person....Donald Trump
QuestionNote: This question was asked as part of an experiment to investigate whether media accounts contribute to the persistence of biological racism among White Americans. The total 2,034 White, non-Hispanic adult respondents were assigned randomly to two treatment groups (race as genetics condition or race as social construction condition) or a control. Respondents were then asked questions intended to measure feelings regarding whether biological racial differences exist, three strikes legislation, the death penalty, and racial resentment. This allowed for deeper understanding of whether ostensibly innocuous messages about race, health, and genetics have consequences on public attitudes towards race.
SubPopulation: Asked of control group, respondents who read no fictitious news articles about racial disparities in heart disease (n=661)
SourceDoc: TESS Survey
SampleDesc: National White, non-Hispanic adults who completed the Public Affairs profile survey
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote:
Weighted results shown. Individual-level unweighted data with weight variable available for download 
for further analyses. Full treatment information available in Downloads.

QuestionTxt: (For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too....Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

IntMethod: Telephone Interview
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (Now we'd like your views on some political leaders and groups. Please say whether your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable.)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: PRRI/Brookings Immigration Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
2146 respondents were interviewed online, and 461 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national U.S. adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC¿s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

QuestionTxt: (Do you have a favorable or unfavorable view of the following individuals?...Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable, don't have enough information to rate, never heard of)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Young Americans' Attitudes toward Politics and Public Service Survey
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to 'self-select' into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Funding was provided by the 11th Hour Project, the Energy Foundation, the Grantham Foundation, and the V.K. Rasmussen Foundation.

Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one.)...How do you feel about Donald Trump?
SourceDoc: Quinnipiac University Poll
IntMethod: Telephone Interview
StudyNote: The interviews included landline and cell phones.

QuestionTxt: (For each of the following individuals, please select if you have a favorable or unfavorable impression of that person. If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too....Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable, don't know enough to say)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll
IntMethod: Web-based survey
StudyNote: The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

QuestionTxt: (Now we'd like your views on some political leaders or groups. Please say whether your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable.)...Donald Trump
SourceDoc: Public Religion Research Institute American Values Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
2297 respondents were interviewed online, and 398 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national U.S. adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC¿s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

If you don't know enough about the person to have an opinion, you can say that too.)...Donald Trump...Very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable
SurveyOrg: AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research
SourceDoc: Associated Press-NORC GenForward Survey
IntMethod: Telephone Interview; Web-based survey
StudyNote:
1788 respondents were interviewed online, and 177 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC¿s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month.

1788 respondents were interviewed online, and 177 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national US adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC¿s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.
45% of completed interviews are sourced from Amerispeak, and 55% of completed interviews are sourced from a panel of young adults custom built by NORC. The Young Adult sample is from a probability-based household panel that uses an address based sample from a registered voter database of the entire US. Households were selected using stratified random sampling to support over-sampling of households with African Americans, Hispanics, and Asians ages 18-30. NORC contacted sampled households by US mail and by telephone, inviting them to register and participate in public opinion surveys twice a month.
